questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing heartburn for the last few months. During this period, she has taken famotidine several times a day without relief and has lost 10 kg (22 lbs). She has retrosternal pressure and burning with every meal. She has had heartburn for several years and took famotidine as needed. She has hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks one glass of wine occasionally. Other current medications include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. She appears pale. Her height is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in), weight is 75 kg (165 lbs), and BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
78 μm


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin

23 pg/cell


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



Platelet count
330,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

137 mEq/L


K+

3.8 mEq/L


Cl-

100 mEq/L


HCO3-

25 mEq/L


Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL


Lactate dehydrogenase
260 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
18 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
15 U/L


Lipase
40 U/L (N < 280)


Troponin I
0.029 ng/mL


An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST-T changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Twenty-four-hour esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected nonerosive reflux disease. While this patient presents with retrosternal chest pain and a burning sensation with meals, suggesting acid reflux, the next step in management should rule out a potential malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is useful to visualize the entire thorax, including the lungs and the mediastinum. Although this patient presents with red flag symptoms of esophageal malignancy, a CT is more appropriate during the staging process after a malignancy has been confirmed.

C) INCORRECT:

An empiric trial of proton-pump inhibitors may be administered if gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is clinically suspected and there are no indications for further diagnostic testing. Although this patient presents with symptoms of heartburn that may suggest GERD, she also has alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia) for esophageal cancer, which must be ruled out first.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry can be used to diagnose motor disorders of the esophagus, e.g., achalasia or esophageal spasms, which may also present with retrosternal pain and weight loss. Because this patient presents with additional alarm symptoms for esophageal malignancy, another diagnostic test is preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow can be used to identify anatomical defects in the esophagus. It is indicated as the initial step in the evaluation of patients with features suggestive of proximal esophageal obstruction, as well as in patients with complicated esophageal strictures (secondary to surgery/radiation/caustic injuries) or with a suspected tracheoesophageal fistula. However, it is not typically considered the best initial step for the evaluation of dysphagia in patients with symptoms predominantly affecting the lower esophagus (e.g., retrosternal pain, heartburn).

F) CORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the best initial and confirmatory test for suspected esophageal cancer and can also be used to classify reflux esophagitis as well as to detect a peptic ulcer. It should be conducted in all patients presenting with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation) and additional alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia, melena, dysphagia). If a biopsy confirms esophageal cancer in this patient, further staging of the disease will include an endoscopic ultrasound to determine the infiltration depth and register regional lymph node disease as well as a chest and abdominal PET‑CT. Treatment depends on the exact location of the tumor, histopathologic type (adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma), and the stage.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

An exophytic, irregularly demarcated mass with raised edges (green line) and central ulceration (dashed line) is partially obstructing the esophageal lumen.
questions.hint: Increasing retrosternal pain, weight loss, and anemia in this patient with long-standing reflux and a 40 pack-year smoking history raise suspicion for esophageal cancer. She has risk factors for both adenocarcinoma (gastroesophageal reflux, smoking) and squamous cell carcinoma (alcohol consumption, smoking) of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive difficulty swallowing and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He first had trouble swallowing solid foods and then also developed difficulty swallowing liquids over the past week. Endoscopy shows a large mass 3 cm proximal to the esophagogastric junction. Biopsy of the mass shows significant distortion of glandular architecture. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrophic gastritis increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Bacterial overgrowth in the achlorhydric stomach generates reactive carcinogenic nitrogen products that can induce eSCC transformation. Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Atrophic gastritis is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic consumption of hot liquids and food increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC) due to thermal damage of the esophageal mucosa. The resulting inflammation stimulates the production of reactive nitrogen species, which are carcinogenic. Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Consumption of hot liquids is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic and excessive alcohol consumption increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, biopsy findings would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. While chronic alcohol use can cause gastroesophageal reflux disease, alcohol consumption has not been associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Moreover, another predisposing factor is more strongly associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Obesity is an important risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Although the exact mechanism is unknown, it is hypothesized that obesity increases the risk of adenocarcinoma by increasing the risk of reflux and via mechanisms independent of reflux. Gastroesophageal reflux disease induces metaplasia (Barrett esophagus), which can progress to adenocarcinoma. In addition, excessive visceral fat increases the risk of inflammation, the production of cytokines and growth factors, and insulin resistance, all of which are risk factors for carcinoma. Other risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma include smoking, achalasia, and certain diets (high in animal protein or cholesterol, low in fiber). Smoking and achalasia furthermore increase the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic consumption of nitrosamine-rich foods (e.g., bacon, other cured meats, pickles, alcohol) is associated with an increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (eSCC). Although eSCC manifests with dysphagia and weight loss, as seen in this patient, a biopsy would show pathognomonic circular areas of keratinization. Consumption of cured meats is not associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
questions.hint: Visualization of a mass in the distal third of the esophagus with histopathologic examination that shows distorted glandular architecture confirms a diagnosis of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Endoscopy shows salmon pink mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show nonciliated columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fungal infection of the lower esophagus
Incomplete relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic proliferation of esophageal epithelium is seen in esophageal cancer. This patient is at increased risk to develop esophageal adenocarcinoma. However, he lacks typical features of an esophageal malignancy such as weight loss, dysphagia, and an ulcerative mass on endoscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic exposure to gastric acid promotes transformation of the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to metaplastic columnar epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett esophagus). Barrett esophagus classically occurs in patients with GERD, which commonly presents with intermittent retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient. Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires histologic confirmation of intestinal metaplasia.
Image Description:

Comparison of the mucous membrane of a normal distal esophagus to one affected by Barrett metaplasia: In reflux esophagitis, stomach acid damages the stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus, which then becomes replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Atopic inflammation of the esophagus is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, which is thought to be caused by an abnormal response of the immune system to an antigenic stimulus. Affected individuals commonly present with retrosternal pain, dysphagia to solids, and food impaction. Although this patient presents with retrosternal pain, biopsy would likely show numerous eosinophils within multiple layers of the esophagus rather than metaplastic changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypermotile esophageal contractions are seen in spastic disorders of the esophagus (e.g., nutcracker esophagus, diffuse esophageal spasms). Hypermotile esophagus may present with sudden, retrosternal chest pain and a distinctive pattern on barium swallow and manometry. Although this patient does have intermittent retrosternal pain, those conditions would not usually present with mucosal abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Fungal infection of the esophagus can be caused by pathogens such as Candida albicans (esophageal candidiasis). Although it may cause retrosternal pain, as seen here, the absence of risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression) and fungal patches on endoscopy make this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter occurs in patients with achalasia due to absent or decreased myenteric neurons. Although achalasia can manifest with retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient, it would classically also present with regurgitation and dysphagia of solids and liquids. Endoscopy could possibly show inflammation in case of retained food, but intestinal metaplasia would not be expected.
questions.hint: Esophageal mucosa is normally whitish-pink and composed of stratified squamous epithelium. Intestinal mucosa is normally composed of columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of bad breath and progressive difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An upper endoscopy is performed and a photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen obtained from the mid-esophagus is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the biopsy findings?

choices.text: Atrophy and fibrosis of the esophageal smooth muscle
Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophageal walls

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Well-differentiated neoplastic glandular proliferation is associated with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, which can manifest with progressive dysphagia and halitosis. Biopsy would, however, not show clusters of keratin pearls but rather high-grade dysplasia of columnar epithelium with adjacent Barrett mucosa. In addition, adenocarcinoma typically involves the lower third rather than the middle of the esophagus.

B) INCORRECT:

Atrophy and fibrosis of the esophageal smooth muscle can be seen in CREST syndrome or systemic sclerosis. These diagnoses may manifest with dysphagia and halitosis in the setting of severe esophageal dysmotility. However, biopsy findings would not show keratinization but rather fibroblast proliferation and smooth muscle atrophy. Moreover, patients with either condition typically present with other findings such as sclerodactyly and Raynaud phenomenon.

C) INCORRECT:

Metaplastic transformation of esophageal mucosa is seen in Barrett esophagus, which can manifest with halitosis, as seen in this patient. However, biopsy would not show the keratin pearls seen here. Instead, it would typically show an extension of the physiologic transformation zone as esophageal squamous epithelium is replaced with intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) CORRECT:

Neoplastic proliferation of squamous epithelium is the hallmark of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the esophagus, which can manifest with progressive dysphagia and halitosis due to food particles retained in the esophagus. The histopathology involves clusters of keratin pearls destroying normal tissue structure in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus. It typically affects patients with risk factors such as long-term alcohol use, tobacco exposure, achalasia, and diets low in fruits and vegetables.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophageal walls is associated with eosinophilic esophagitis, which can manifest with dysphagia and, in some cases, halitosis due to food impaction. However, biopsy would not show the keratin pearls seen in this patient. Instead, it would show circumferential mucosal lesions and, possibly, eosinophilic infiltration. Moreover, patients with eosinophilic esophagitis typically present with a history of allergic disease as well as acute symptoms associated with exposure to a particular food.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of esophageal epithelial tissue (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are a large number of eosinophils present (examples indicated by green overlay). Some of these are clustered into eosinophilic microabscesses (white arrowheads), which are characteristic of eosinophilic esophagitis and help to differentiate it histologically from reflux esophagitis (in which there may also be many eosinophils present). The dilated intercellular spaces (black arrows) are a non-specific feature that is also present in reflux esophagitis.
questions.hint: The concentric eosinophilic lesions seen in this image are known as keratin pearls.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of poorly controlled acid reflux symptoms. He uses over-the-counter omeprazole, which partially relieves his symptoms. He reports consuming approximately 30 mL of whiskey per day.
His BMI is 35; otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable.
He had an upper endoscopy 6 months ago, which showed evidence of a hiatal hernia and Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia. A carbon-13 urea breath test is positive.
For which type of cancer is this patient most at risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer and squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus, but not esophageal adenocarcinoma. The annual incidence of pancreatic cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for these cancers.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma, including Barrett esophagus, chronic reflux esophagitis, hiatal hernia, male sex, and obesity. In patients with Barrett esophagus, the annual risk of esophageal cancer is approximately 6% for those with high-grade dysplasia and 0.25% for those without dysplasia.

Key learning point: The cancer most typically associated with Barrett esophagus and hiatal hernia is esophageal adenocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

H. pylori infection also increases the risk for mucosal-associated lymphoid tumors, particularly when gastric atrophy is also present, but the incidence of this type of tumor is low (approximately 2 in 100,000 patients per year).

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer and squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus, but not esophageal adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Helicobacter pylori (which can be inferred from the positive carbon-13 urea breath test) increases the risk for gastric cancer, but this risk is small. The annual incidence of gastric cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man visiting the United States from El Salvador reports a 3-month history of progressive dysphagia. He has difficulty swallowing solid foods and occasionally liquids, but he has a good functional status. He has had intermittent heartburn and regurgitation for the past year but denies odynophagia. He takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension but denies use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, alcohol, or tobacco.
His current vital signs include a heart rate of 91 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 121/60 mm Hg. His chest and abdominal examinations are unremarkable, but his stool is black. His hematocrit is 22.9% (reference range, 41.0–53.0), down from 45.0% two years ago. Other laboratory results include a mean corpuscular volume of 70 μm3 (80–100), a platelet count of 269,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000), a serum creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL (0.8–1.3), and an international normalized ratio of 1.0.
The patient is admitted to the hospital, where upper endoscopy reveals extrinsic compression of the distal esophagus and a large, fungating, circumferential mass in the gastric cardia. Biopsies are obtained, and results are pending.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this patient?

choices.text: Balloon dilation of the distal esophagus
Positron emission tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
Endoscopic ultrasound of the gastric cardia mass
CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Balloon dilation is unlikely to be effective in this setting and would carry a high risk for perforation. Balloon dilation may be appropriate for palliation for carefully selected patients who have poor functional status.

B) INCORRECT:

No other management options are indicated until the CT scan establishes whether the patient has obvious metastatic disease. Depending on the CT results, further testing could be pursued before selecting treatment. Testing options include positron emission tomography (PET), endoscopic ultrasound of the mass to assess local depth of invasion (particularly if CT reveals no metastasis) and regional nodal involvement, and exploratory laparoscopy to assess for distant metastases.

C) INCORRECT:

No other management options are indicated until the CT scan establishes whether the patient has obvious metastatic disease. Depending on the CT results, further testing could be pursued before selecting treatment. Testing options include positron emission tomography (PET), endoscopic ultrasound of the mass to assess local depth of invasion (particularly if CT reveals no metastasis) and regional nodal involvement, and exploratory laparoscopy to assess for distant metastases. Although PET imaging is sensitive for the detection of distant metastases, this case lacks tissue confirmation of malignancy. Confirmation of locoregional spread is more sensitively detected by CT imaging and is indicated in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

No other management options are indicated until the CT scan establishes whether the patient has obvious metastatic disease. Depending on the CT results, further testing could be pursued before selecting treatment. Testing options include positron emission tomography (PET), endoscopic ultrasound of the mass to assess local depth of invasion (particularly if CT reveals no metastasis) and regional nodal involvement, and exploratory laparoscopy to assess for distant metastases.

E) CORRECT:

Dysphagia is a common presenting feature of a stricture in the esophagus. The most common malignant cause of stricture in the esophagus is gastroesophageal cancer. After endoscopy, which can obtain biopsies to determine tissue type and define the anatomic extent of the tumor, CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis should be conducted to evaluate for metastatic disease.

No other management options are indicated until the CT scan establishes whether the patient has obvious metastatic disease. Depending on the CT results, further testing could be pursued before selecting treatment. Testing options include positron emission tomography (PET), endoscopic ultrasound of the mass to assess local depth of invasion (particularly if CT reveals no metastasis) and regional nodal involvement, and exploratory laparoscopy to assess for distant metastases. Although PET imaging is sensitive for the detection of distant metastases, this case lacks tissue confirmation of malignancy. Confirmation of locoregional spread is more sensitively detected by CT imaging and is indicated in this case.

Balloon dilation is unlikely to be effective in this setting and would carry a high risk for perforation. Balloon dilation may be appropriate for palliation for carefully selected patients who have poor functional status.

Key learning point: The most appropriate imaging to evaluate an esophageal stricture in a patient with an endoscopy-identified gastric cardia mass is CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis for staging.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with previously diagnosed hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and a 25-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents for evaluation of heartburn. He has been taking omeprazole 20 mg by mouth daily for the past 8 years, which has generally controlled his reflux symptoms, but he is now having heartburn after meals 2 to 3 nights weekly. He reports no nausea, vomiting, or weight loss. He recently underwent cardiac stress testing in the emergency department, which was negative. He has no family history of cancer and had a normal colonoscopy 2 years ago.
On physical examination, he has normal vital signs and is in no acute distress. His oropharyngeal examination is normal, and he has no cervical lymphadenopathy. Heart and lung sounds are normal. His abdomen is soft and nontender, and he has central adiposity.
In addition to increasing the patient’s proton-pump-inhibitor dose, which one of the following tests should be ordered?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study may be useful for evaluating dysphagia and swallowing disorders. It can indicate the presence of an esophageal tumor, diverticulum, or stricture, or suggest certain motility disorders, but it is not useful in evaluating for Barrett esophagus.

B) INCORRECT:

If esophagogastroduodenoscopy does not identify reflux esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or esophageal adenocarcinoma, and the patient’s symptoms do not improve with increased acid suppression, then esophageal pH testing might be useful, to determine whether ongoing acid reflux is contributing to the symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

This male patient, who is age 60 with long-term gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms and a history of smoking, should undergo esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma. Current guidelines recommend considering such evaluation for men who have chronic (>5 years) and/or frequent (at least weekly) symptoms of GERD (heartburn or acid regurgitation) plus two or more of the following risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma:

• Age >50 years
• White race
• Central adiposity (waist circumference >102 cm or waist-to-hip ratio >0.9)
• Current or past history of smoking
• Confirmed family history of BE or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative

Key learning point: Older male smokers who have frequent or chronic heartburn despite proton-pump-inhibitor therapy should undergo evaluation for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis may be useful in determining acute causes of chest and abdominal pain and are often ordered together for staging of malignancy. This patient does not have any clear indication for CT at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiography may be considered in the evaluation of acute abdominal pain when a bowel perforation or obstruction is likely. Such imaging would be of limited value in a patient without reported abdominal tenderness.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes, and a 35-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents for evaluation of progressive difficulty with swallowing. He describes dysphagia to solid foods that has progressively worsened during the past 2 to 3 months. He initially modified his diet but now has difficulty swallowing liquids as well. He reports that anything that he takes by mouth “gets stuck” in his chest, leading to regurgitation and choking episodes. He reports no chest pain, fever, or heartburn. He has lost 8.2 kg since his last visit one year ago.
Which one of the following tests should this patient undergo now?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH testing is useful in the evaluation of suspected gastroesophageal reflux disease, including the evaluation of atypical chest pain; however, it is not a first-line test in patients with esophageal dysphagia, as malignancy must be ruled out first.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is used to evaluate for esophageal motility disorders (such as achalasia) and may eventually be considered in this patient if there is no evidence of a structural cause for his symptoms on another initial test.

C) INCORRECT:

A modified barium swallow study is used to evaluate oropharyngeal dysphagia. Oropharyngeal dysphagia may occur with liquids or solids and may lead to aspiration. In contrast, esophageal dysphagia is often characterized by the feeling that solids are “stuck” in the chest area. Given the localization of this patient’s symptoms to the chest rather than the neck, esophageal dysphagia is more likely than oropharyngeal dysphagia

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study, or barium esophagram, can be used to evaluate esophageal dysphagia and can provide a general sense of both the structure and motility of the esophagus. However, this patient has symptoms of progressive esophageal dysphagia, a history of smoking, and recent weight loss, thereby heightening the concern for esophageal cancer. Of note, a barium swallow study may be better at diagnosing a Zenker diverticulum in the proximal esophagus, which can cause oropharyngeal dysphagia and food regurgitation, but in this patient, malignancy should be excluded first.

E) CORRECT:

Esophageal cancer is the primary diagnosis to exclude in this patient.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the best initial test, as it allows for direct visualization, tissue biopsy, and potential therapy, including hemostasis and stenting. EGD can also detect other causes of dysphagia, including esophagitis, esophageal strictures, and rings, but these conditions are less likely to cause weight loss unless the patient’s oral intake is significantly reduced.

Key learning point: A middle-aged patient with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a history of cigarette smoking should be evaluated with esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents with four months of progressive difficulty swallowing, initially with solids and now involving liquids, and has unintentionally lost 9 kg. He denies heartburn or notable regurgitation but experiences occasional chest discomfort after meals. He has a 40-year history of heavy smoking. On examination, he appears mildly pale with no palpable lymphadenopathy.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peptic strictures result from chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, requiring years of persistent symptoms like heartburn. The absence of reflux history and rapid symptom progression with weight loss suggest a different etiology, inconsistent with peptic strictures.

B) CORRECT:

Esophageal cancer manifests with progressive dysphagia, initially affecting solids and later involving liquids, due to a narrowing esophageal lumen from a growing mass. The patient's significant weight loss reflects reduced intake and systemic effects of malignancy. A 40-year history of heavy smoking is a major risk factor for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma, common in older adults. Occasional postprandial chest discomfort may result from local irritation or disrupted motility by the tumor. Endoscopic examination and biopsy confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Progressive dysphagia for solids and liquids, along with significant weight loss in an older adult, is highly suggestive of oesophageal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain, not progressive symptoms. The gradual worsening of dysphagia and significant weight loss indicate a structural obstruction rather than a motility disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Achalasia typically presents with simultaneous dysphagia for solids and liquids due to lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction, not a progression from solids to liquids. It is more common in younger individuals and often involves significant regurgitation, which is absent here.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of progressively worsening dysphagia, initially to solids and now including liquids, and a 7 kg weight loss. He has a 30-year history of heavy alcohol use and a 20-year history of cigarette smoking. Over the past two weeks, he has noticed dark stools on several occasions and feels increasingly fatigued. He has no history of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms and denies odynophagia or chest pain. Physical examination shows pallor of the conjunctiva (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
95 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and then to liquids, suggests an obstructive esophageal lesion. His history of heavy alcohol use and smoking increases the risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma due to chronic mucosal irritation. The significant weight loss and anemia, indicated by dark stools, suggest tumor-related bleeding, likely from ulceration. The absence of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms reduces the likelihood of adenocarcinoma, further supporting squamous cell carcinoma given the patient's risk factors and clinical presentation.

Key learning point: Progressive dysphagia and weight loss in an elderly patient with a history of alcohol use are suggestive of esophageal cancer, especially when accompanied by anemia and altered stool color indicating possible gastrointestinal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Zenker diverticulum presents with oropharyngeal dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis, not progressive dysphagia from solids to liquids. It does not typically cause significant weight loss or gastrointestinal bleeding. The absence of regurgitation or halitosis further reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Achalasia usually causes dysphagia to both solids and liquids from the onset. It is not associated with gastrointestinal bleeding or significant weight loss due to chronic blood loss. The absence of regurgitation or esophageal stasis symptoms also makes achalasia less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Peptic strictures result from chronic acid exposure and are usually preceded by gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, which are absent here. The progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and bleeding are less characteristic of peptic strictures. The patient's history of alcohol and smoking suggests a different esophageal pathology.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a long-standing history of poorly controlled acid reflux symptoms. He uses over-the-counter omeprazole, which provides partial relief. He consumes about 30 mL of whiskey daily. His BMI is 35. Six months ago, he underwent upper endoscopy, which showed a hiatal hernia and Barrett esophagus with high-grade dysplasia. A carbon-13 urea breath test is positive. Which one of the following conditions is this patient at greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer. The annual incidence of pancreatic cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for this cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Helicobacter pylori (which can be inferred from the positive carbon-13 urea breath test) increases the risk of gastric cancer, but this risk is small. The annual incidence of gastric cancer is approximately 1 in 10,000 patients.

C) INCORRECT:

H. pylori infection also increases the risk for mucosal-associated lymphoid tumors, particularly when gastric atrophy is also present, but the incidence of this type of tumor is low (approximately 2 in 100,000 patients per year).

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk for several types of cancer, including squamous-cell carcinoma of the esophagus. Consuming 30 mL of whiskey daily does not substantially increase the risk for this cancer.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma, including Barrett esophagus, chronic reflux esophagitis, hiatal hernia, male sex, and obesity. In patients with Barrett esophagus, the annual risk of esophageal cancer is approximately 6% for those with high-grade dysplasia and 0.25% for those without dysplasia.

Key learning point: The cancer most typically associated with Barrett esophagus and hiatal hernia is esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and a 25-pack-year smoking history comes to your clinic for evaluation of heartburn. He has been taking omeprazole for the past 8 years, but now experiences heartburn after meals 2 to 3 nights per week. On examination, he has central adiposity. In addition to increasing his proton-pump inhibitor dose, which one of the following tests should you order?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis may be useful in determining acute causes of chest and abdominal pain and are often ordered together for staging of malignancy. This patient does not have any clear indication for CT at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiography may be considered in the evaluation of acute abdominal pain when a bowel perforation or obstruction is likely. Such imaging would be of limited value in a patient without reported abdominal tenderness.

C) CORRECT:

This male patient, who is age 60 with long-term gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms and a history of smoking, should undergo esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma. Current guidelines recommend considering such evaluation for men who have chronic (>5 years) and/or frequent (at least weekly) symptoms of GERD (heartburn or acid regurgitation) plus two or more of the following risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma:

• Age >50 years
• White race
• Central adiposity (waist circumference >102 cm or waist-to-hip ratio >0.9)
• Current or past history of smoking
• Confirmed family history of BE or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative

Key learning point: Older male smokers who have frequent or chronic heartburn despite proton-pump-inhibitor therapy should undergo evaluation for Barrett esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study may be useful for evaluating dysphagia and swallowing disorders. It can indicate the presence of an esophageal tumor, diverticulum, or stricture, or suggest certain motility disorders, but it is not useful in evaluating for Barrett esophagus.

E) INCORRECT:

If esophagogastroduodenoscopy does not identify reflux esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or esophageal adenocarcinoma, and the patient’s symptoms do not improve with increased acid suppression, then esophageal pH testing might be useful, to determine whether ongoing acid reflux is contributing to the symptoms.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of increasing heartburn over the past few months. She reports taking famotidine several times a day without relief and has lost 10 kg during this period. She experiences retrosternal pressure and burning with every meal. She has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one glass of wine occasionally. On abdominal examination, there is mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies reveal anemia. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is useful to visualize the entire thorax, including the lungs and the mediastinum. Although this patient presents with red flag symptoms of esophageal malignancy, a CT is more appropriate during the staging process after a malignancy has been confirmed.

B) CORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the best initial and confirmatory test for suspected esophageal cancer and can also be used to classify reflux esophagitis as well as to detect a peptic ulcer. It should be conducted in all patients presenting with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation) and additional alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia, melena, dysphagia). If a biopsy confirms esophageal cancer in this patient, further staging of the disease will include an endoscopic ultrasound to determine the infiltration depth and register regional lymph node disease as well as a chest and abdominal PET‑CT. Treatment depends on the exact location of the tumor, histopathologic type (adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma), and the stage.

Key learning point: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the initial diagnostic test of choice for suspected esophageal cancer in patients with alarm symptoms.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

An exophytic, irregularly demarcated mass with raised edges (green line) and central ulceration (dashed line) is partially obstructing the esophageal lumen.

C) INCORRECT:

An empiric trial of proton-pump inhibitors may be administered if gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is clinically suspected and there are no indications for further diagnostic testing. Although this patient presents with symptoms of heartburn that may suggest GERD, she also has alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia) for esophageal cancer, which must be ruled out first.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow can be used to identify anatomical defects in the esophagus. It is indicated as the initial step in the evaluation of patients with features suggestive of proximal esophageal obstruction, as well as in patients with complicated esophageal strictures (secondary to surgery/radiation/caustic injuries) or with a suspected tracheoesophageal fistula. It is not the best initial step to rule out esophageal cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Twenty-four-hour esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected nonerosive reflux disease. While this patient presents with retrosternal chest pain and a burning sensation with meals, suggesting acid reflux, she also has alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia) for esophageal cancer, which must be ruled out first.

She has risk factors for both adenocarcinoma (gastroesophageal reflux, smoking) and squamous cell carcinoma (alcohol consumption, smoking) of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of difficulty swallowing solid foods and an 8-pound weight loss. He reports no liquid dysphagia but notes occasional substernal discomfort after meals. He was diagnosed with Barrett esophagus 5 years ago during routine surveillance for longstanding gastroesophageal reflux disease. He continues smoking despite previous counseling and has a 25-pack-year history. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination shows no palpable lymphadenopathy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT chest and abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitor therapy is inappropriate in a patient with Barrett esophagus, progressive structural dysphagia, weight loss, and high-risk features. These red flags require urgent tissue diagnosis rather than empiric acid suppression.

B) INCORRECT:

CT is useful for staging confirmed malignancy but does not provide tissue diagnosis. This patient’s clinical presentation with high-risk features requires histopathological confirmation rather than imaging alone.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for diagnosing esophageal motility disorders but should only be performed after structural and inflammatory lesions have been ruled out. This patient has Barrett esophagus, progressive solid food dysphagia, weight loss, and high-risk features; urgent tissue diagnosis is indicated, not motility assessment.

D) INCORRECT:

Barium swallow may show structural abnormalities such as apple core lesions but cannot provide tissue diagnosis. Another diagnostic modality is more appropriate for suspected malignancy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's progressive solid food dysphagia, weight loss, Barrett esophagus, and smoking history represent high risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy provides direct visualization and tissue sampling for definitive histopathological diagnosis, making it the most appropriate initial diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of trouble swallowing solid foods like bread and meat. He now also struggles with liquids. He reports an unintentional 15-lb (7 kg) weight loss over the same period. He has a 20-year history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, for which he takes omeprazole daily. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Physical examination is unremarkable. Routine laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is an essential part of the workup for esophageal cancer, but its primary role is in staging the disease after a diagnosis has been made. It helps determine the extent of local tumor invasion, assess for lymph node involvement, and identify distant metastases. It is not the primary modality for making the initial tissue diagnosis of the esophageal lesion itself.

B) INCORRECT:

24-hour esophageal pH monitoring measures the amount of acid refluxing into the esophagus over a 24-hour period and is used to diagnose or quantify gastroesophageal reflux disease. While the patient has a history of GERD, his current presentation with red flags like progressive dysphagia and weight loss necessitates an evaluation for malignancy, not a confirmation of his known GERD diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A barium esophagogram is an imaging study that can identify structural abnormalities like strictures, rings, or large masses within the esophagus. While it can be an initial test for dysphagia, it is less sensitive for detecting early mucosal lesions and cannot provide a tissue sample for diagnosis. Given the high suspicion for malignancy based on alarm symptoms, proceeding directly to endoscopy for definitive diagnosis is more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice in suspected esophageal cancer, as it allows for direct visualization of the esophageal mucosa to identify any masses, strictures, or ulcerations. It also enables the collection of tissue samples for histopathologic analysis, which is required to confirm the diagnosis of malignancy. The two main types of esophageal cancer are adenocarcinoma, associated with chronic GERD and Barrett esophagus, and squamous cell carcinoma, associated with smoking and alcohol use.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry measures pressures and coordination of muscle contractions in the esophagus. It is the diagnostic standard for motility disorders such as achalasia or diffuse esophageal spasm. This patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia, starting with solids, strongly suggest a mechanical obstruction rather than a primary motility issue, making manometry an inappropriate initial test.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia (solids then liquids) and unintentional weight loss, together with his advanced age, history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and smoking history, raise suspicion for esophageal cancer.
